fields.description: /etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d is the memo section of eucalyptus-cloud.  It contains a mishmash of scripts, jmx bits, and internal configuration stuff, only some of which is used.  What actually makes it a problem, though, is that eucalyptus-cloud creates that directory shortly after it starts.  That is going to break on RHEL 7, so we should put it somewhere else, such as under /var/lib/eucalyptus or /run/eucalyptus, instead.

comments.body:
On a build from source this is what is present under cloud.d:

{code}
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/www
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/www/admin.xml
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/init.d
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/init.d/01_pg_kernel_params
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/notifications.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_persistence.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/walruslogger.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/notifications_digest.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/initialize_cloud.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_persistence_remote.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_dbpool.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_db.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/stats_sensors.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_membership.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_dbpool_remote.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/reports
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/conf
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/security.policy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2015_05.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2011_08.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2014_10.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2015_02.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2014_01.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/jmx
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/jmx/com.eucalyptus.component.Component
{code}

the following are removed for 4.3:

{code}
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/www
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/www/admin.xml
{code}

we could also remove:

{code}
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/walruslogger.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_persistence_remote.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_dbpool_remote.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/reports
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/conf
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/security.policy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/jmx
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/jmx/com.eucalyptus.component.Component
{code}

which would leave the following:

{code}
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/init.d
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/init.d/01_pg_kernel_params
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/notifications.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_persistence.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/notifications_digest.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/initialize_cloud.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_dbpool.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_db.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/stats_sensors.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_membership.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2015_05.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2011_08.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2014_10.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2015_02.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2014_01.json
{code}

The "init.d" script could be moved directly into the service scripts if desired.

The "scripts" directory could be moved to "var" as long as we do not expect these scripts to be modified.

The "elb-security-policy" directory may need to be moved if ELB becomes a UFS service (as having configuration on the file system is fragile if multiple hosts must be configured)
Please, provide the list of files, [~gholms]. Thanks!

Here are the bits under that directory that are included at packaging time:

{noformat}
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/conf
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2011_08.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2014_01.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2014_10.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2015_02.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2015_05.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/init.d
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/jmx
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/jmx/com.eucalyptus.component.Component
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/initialize_cloud.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/notifications.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/notifications_digest.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_db.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_dbpool.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_dbpool_remote.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_membership.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_persistence.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_persistence_remote.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/stats_sensors.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/walruslogger.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/security.policy
{noformat}

The main thing that strikes me as absent from this list is that script that sets sysctl values for postgresql, which we don't need on RHEL 7.  Perhaps that script could simply move somewhere else that the RHEL 6 init script can call, and then we can remove that later.

Unless they are meant to be changed by the user, these are all _still_ in the wrong directory, but at least we can hopefully get by without allowing writes to that directory.  I wonder if eucalyptus-cloud will refuse to run when denied permission to do that.

It is still not clear to me which files/directories are causing issues, but I assume that if I remove any unnecessary files/directories from under /etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d and ensure the service starts without write access to /etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d then this issue is addressed.

That sounds like a good first step, at the very least.  I can't recall whether it tries to write those files before or after dropping privileges, but if nothing else we'll find out after applying an selinux policy to it.

There is now an internal dev-sjones-euca-12005 branch that has the following cloud.d contents:

{code}
# find /etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/init.d
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/init.d/01_pg_kernel_params
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2014_10.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2014_01.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2011_08.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2015_02.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/elb-security-policy/elb_security_policy_2015_05.json
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_persistence_remote.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_db.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/stats_sensors.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_membership.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_dbpool_remote.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/notifications_digest.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_dbpool.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/setup_persistence.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/initialize_cloud.groovy
/etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d/scripts/notifications.groovy
{code}

This most likely requires packaging changes due to the removed files.

[~gholms], let me know if I should merge these changes or if we need to coordinate merging this branch and any associated packaging updates.
[~gholms], let me know how you would like to proceed with this issue.
The fix for 4.3 is to remove content from /etc/eucalyptus/cloud.d where possible (as described in previous comment)

Verified that the same list of files presents on install from packages
